# which

Like the unix which utility.

Finds the first instance of a specified executable in the PATH environment variable. Does not cache the results, so hash -r is not needed when the PATH changes.

## USAGE

```javascript var which = require(‘which’)

// async usage which(‘node’, function (er, resolvedPath) {

// er is returned if no “node” is found on the PATH // if it is found, then the absolute path to the exec is returned

})

// sync usage // throws if not found var resolved = which.sync(‘node’)

// Pass options to override the PATH and PATHEXT environment vars. which(‘node’, { path: someOtherPath }, function (er, resolved) {

if (er)
throw er

console.log(‘found at %j’, resolved)

})¶

## OPTIONS

If you pass in options, then path and pathExt are relevant.
